content: I liked what E.L. Lewis had to say about it: quote: Let us assume that sometimes torture sometimes is effective. Let us also ignore the question of whether it is more effective than other techniques. Virtually all of the empirical evidence shows that torture is usually ineffective and is almost invariably less effective than other methods of interrogation. Also, tortured confessions frequently generate massive amounts of false information, leading to endless and costly false leads, and in turn, to a round robin of further interrogations of those wrongly identified. But it is wrong to engage in the discussion whether torture is effective policy. The absolute prohibition on torture is not based on a consensus that it never works. Rather, it is based on the sad realization that the impulse to torture is ever-present; that human beings who are frightened or zealous or full of rage -- as human beings invariably are -- will feel a powerful need to torture and a powerful justification for acting on that need. It is useful to recall the understandable fear and anger after September 11 not to justify or excuse torture, but to understand that it is precisely at the moment of most stress that the norm against torture must be powerfully affirmed.

content: I liked what E.L. Lewis had to say about it: quote: Let us assume that sometimes torture sometimes is effective. Let us also ignore the question of whether it is more effective than other techniques. Virtually all of the empirical evidence shows that torture is usually ineffective and is almost invariably less effective than other methods of interrogation. Also, tortured confessions frequently generate massive amounts of false information, leading to endless and costly false leads, and in turn, to a round robin of further interrogations of those wrongly identified. But it is wrong to engage in the discussion whether torture is effective policy. The absolute prohibition on torture is not based on a consensus that it never works. Rather, it is based on the sad realization that the impulse to torture is ever-present; that human beings who are frightened or zealous or full of rage -- as human beings invariably are -- will feel a powerful need to torture and a powerful justification for acting on that need. It is useful to recall the understandable fear and anger after September 11 not to justify or excuse torture, but to understand that it is precisely at the moment of most stress that the norm against torture must be powerfully affirmed.

content: I liked what E.L. Lewis had to say about it: quote: Let us assume that sometimes torture sometimes is effective. Let us also ignore the question of whether it is more effective than other techniques. Virtually all of the empirical evidence shows that torture is usually ineffective and is almost invariably less effective than other methods of interrogation. Also, tortured confessions frequently generate massive amounts of false information, leading to endless and costly false leads, and in turn, to a round robin of further interrogations of those wrongly identified. But it is wrong to engage in the discussion whether torture is effective policy. The absolute prohibition on torture is not based on a consensus that it never works. Rather, it is based on the sad realization that the impulse to torture is ever-present; that human beings who are frightened or zealous or full of rage -- as human beings invariably are -- will feel a powerful need to torture and a powerful justification for acting on that need. It is useful to recall the understandable fear and anger after September 11 not to justify or excuse torture, but to understand that it is precisely at the moment of most stress that the norm against torture must be powerfully affirmed.

content: I managed to interrogate many North Vietnamese soldiers, Viet Cong and Vietnamese civilians during my time in Viet-Nam. I got good, quality intelligence out of the majority of them - and never had to use torture (pardon me, "enhanced interrogation techniques"). During my time in Germany working in counter-intelligence, I interrogated Russian agents, East German agents, Bulgarian agents, Polish agents, etc. I got good, quality intelligence out of the majority of them - and never had to use torture (pardon me, "enhanced interrogation techniques"). Some of that intelliegence was tactical, some was strategic and it was solid intel - and I never had to use torture (pardon me, "enhanced interrogation techniques"). Use of torture (pardon me, "enhanced interrogation techniques") leads to false intelligence and inevitably wastes time since the subject will lie to stop/delay the torture (pardon me, "enhanced interrogation techniques"). In re the OP's question, you never let someone with emotional ties (i.e. father, husband, brother, mother, wife, sister, etc.) do the interrogation of a suspect - because it is a given that they cannot act in a rational, sane manner during the interrogation. Their quest for vengence/revenge clouds their judgment. In the circumstances of the question, even though I am a trained (and somewhat skilled) interrogator, I would disqualify myself from the interrogation and leave it to someone who could be objective.
